advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD MOTHER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil has a lot of relations"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the pictured floppy drives have never been released.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> END OF LIFE</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the end of 1985, the entire stock of Alphatronic PC and peripherals is sold to brokers which sold them at 25% of the original price.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>“Why be content with a video game system?<br> Today, the VIC-20 is available at a special price.”<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
One of the many "Arcadia 2001 clone" systems. This one was marketed in Germany.
See Emerson Arcadia 2001 for more info.

emulator.description: DOS emulator written by Paul Robson
emulator.name: 2001 - The Emerson Arcadia 2001 Emulator

emulator.description: Nice Arcadia 2001 emulator for Windows (also emulates Interton VC-4000 and clones!)
emulator.name: Emulator2001 by Gavin Turner

emulator.description: Arcadia 2001, Interton VC 4000, Elektor TVGC emulator!
emulator.name: WinArcadia

emulator.description: Arcadia 2001, Interton VC 4000, Elektor TVGC emulator!
emulator.name: AmiArcadia

emulator.description: MESS also emulates Arcadia 2001 & compatible systems
emulator.name: MESS

computer.keyboard: Two detachable controllers made of a screwable joystick, a 12-buttons keypad (0-9, CLEAR, ENTER) and two fire buttons (same function)
computer.name: TVG 2000
computer.rom: None in the conventional sense, though there was some built into the processor chips.
